customData.content: 50-year-old male with a 3-year history of Diabetes Mellitus presents with a 14-day history of non-productive cough, high-grade fever, and right-sided sharp pleuritic chest pain localized to the lower chest. Fever was sudden in onset, progressing from low-grade to high-grade over time, continuous without rigors or chills, and mildly relieved by medication temporarily. The patient previously took Oral Cefixime and Clarithromycin for 4 days with no improvement. Temperature of 103 F and maintained oxygen saturation (SO2) at room air.

HPI.summary: Patient presents with non-productive cough, high-grade fever, and right-sided sharp pleuritic chest pain localized to the lower chest.

customData.content: Exam findings: Dull percussion note at the fourth to fifth intercostal space, with bronchial breathing and increased vocal resonance at the site. Labs: Total leucocyte count (TLC) of 21,000/μL, C‐reactive protein (CRP) of 113 mg/L, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 59 mm/h. Chest x‐ray (CXR) posterior–anterior (PA) view showed a well‐circumscribed homogenous opacification in the right mid‐lower zone, concerning for a mass lesion.

imaging.finding: Well-circumscribed homogenous opacification in the right mid-lower zone

customData.content: Patient was hospitalized and initiated on Intravenous Ceftriaxone 2 g once a day.

Chest computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast revealed the presence of numerous pulmonary nodules dispersed throughout the right lung. Patchy inflammatory alterations were observed at the base of the left lung. A region of soft tissue density was identified in the lower base of the right lung, accompanied by an enlargement of the right hilar lymph node measuring approximately (24 × 12 mm) in diameter. Clarithromycin administration continued.

imaging.finding: numerous pulmonary nodules dispersed throughout the right lung
imaging.impression: presence of numerous pulmonary nodules dispersed throughout the right lung. Patchy inflammatory alterations were observed at the base of the left lung. A region of soft tissue density was identified in the lower base of the right lung, accompanied by an enlargement of the right hilar lymph node measuring approximately (24 × 12 mm) in diameter.

customData.content: Multiple prominent lymph nodes were detected in the right axilla, with the largest measuring about (23 × 9) mm in diameter. Patient experienced episodes of elevated body temperature, characterized by high‐grade fevers mildly alleviated with the administration of paracetamol. Patient had no expectorant, the AFB smear test could be conducted. Patient underwent a lung biopsy procedure with CT guidance.

imaging.impression: Multiple prominent lymph nodes were detected in the right axilla, with the largest measuring about (23 × 9) mm in diameter.
Patient underwent a lung biopsy procedure with CT guidance.

HPI.summary: Patient experienced episodes of elevated body temperature, characterized by high‐grade fevers mildly alleviated with the administration of paracetamol.

customData.content: Lung biopsy revealed chronic granulomatous inflammation characterized by Langerhans‐type multinucleated giant cells and widespread areas of caseous necrosis.

procedures.name: Biopsy
procedures.outcome: Chronic granulomatous inflammation characterized by Langerhans‐type multinucleated giant cells and widespread areas of caseous necrosis

customData.content: Patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) and started on anti‐tuberculosis treatment regime, including rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide in weight-adjusted dosages. Patient was shifted to an isolated room.
Patient was kept under observation for a week until the symptoms resolved.
After 4 weeks post-treatment, a follow-up chest x-ray showed improvement in the consolidation compared to the prior x-ray.

data.content: Patient's condition progresses, with exam findings revealing dull percussion, bronchial breathing, and increased vocal resonance. Labs show elevated TLC, CRP, and ESR. CXR indicates a concerning mass lesion.
Patient is hospitalized and started on intravenous Ceftriaxone.
Chest CT scan reveals numerous pulmonary nodules, patchy inflammatory alterations, and a region of soft tissue density with enlarged hilar lymph node. Clarithromycin administration continued.
Multiple prominent lymph nodes are detected in the right axilla. Patient experiences high-grade fevers, and a lung biopsy is performed with CT guidance.
Lung biopsy reveals chronic granulomatous inflammation with Langerhans-type multinucleated giant cells and caseous necrosis.
Patient is diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and started on anti-tuberculosis treatment (rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide). Patient is shifted to an isolated room.
Patient is kept under observation for a week until the symptoms resolved.
After 4 weeks post-treatment, a follow-up chest x-ray showed improvement in the consolidation compared to the prior x-ray.
